Your skill transcends into artistry - your Automaton's gain proficiency with Deception (+10) for the purposes of appearing to be living creatures, They gain speech (limitedly) and their movements and behavior are disturbingly realistic. Cost of the automatons is doubled. They retain their abilities which often will clearly demonstrate them to be constructs, but a horse, dog, or even child will appear real to the casual inspection. Your Automatons gain +2 bonus to their Intelligence,Wisdom, and a +6 to Charisma ability scores.
{@b Adamantine Automaton}. Your Automaton's gain a +2 bonus on their AC, STRength, DEXterity, and CONsitution ability scores, and gain +10 movement.

subclassFeature.name: Mystic Sage
entries: This Artifier focuses on the creation of goods. Written works in particular, and is horrible at combat.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with two of the following artisan kit/tools; {@item Calligraphy Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb}, {@item Painter's Kit|phb}, {@item Potter's Tools|phb}, {@item Weaver's|Weaver's Tools|phb}, {@item , and Woodworker's Tools|phb}. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan's tools of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Cantrip
entries: You learn 2 Cantrips from the Following List: {@spell Message|phb}, {@spell Guidance|phb}, or {@spell Mage Hand|phb}.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Infusions
entries: You gain one additional infusion of the type Artistic/Wonderous with each level.

items: {@b At 1st level}, you learn Quill of Longwritting and Quill of Dictation.
{@b At 3rd level}, you learn Wand of... and Rune Infusions.
{@b At 5th level}, you learn Reading Glasses, and Cynic's Goggles.
{@b At 7th level}, you learn Goggles of Truesight and Quill of Law.
{@b At 11th level}, you learn Rune of Shadowtendril.
{@b At 17th level}, you learn Bottled Storm.

subclassFeature.name: ReCharged
entries: At 1st level, You may, as a bonus action, use 1 infusion point + 2 points per spell slot level to grant a magic item with a Temporary single charge.

items: {@b At 6th level}, you reduce the infusion cost of making a wand, stave, rod by 1 point (You still may not exceed your Max Infusion cost).

{@b At 12th level}, if you put a charge into an item that broke within the last hour as a result of expending its last charge, you may repair it. (effectively a revify for charged magical items). When you do this, rather than your overcharge granting an additional charge, it returns the item's ability to gain more charges the next day.

entries.name: Alternate Rules:
entries: The Artificer must have one or all of the schema(s) necessary to recharge the item to use this ability.

subclassFeature.name: Enduring Enchantment
entries: {@i (This grants early access of the Enduring Enchantment received at 6th level)}

At 1st level, when you create an infusion you may choose to enhance the dweomer making it last one day.  Doing so costs the Artificer dearly.  In addition to the Infusion point costs the artificer reduces their Maximum Health by that same amount as well as take a point of Constitution damage.  You may not regain the Infusion Point(s), CONstitution damage, and damage from Maximum HP until either the item(s) are broken, used or a week has passed.

items: {@b At 6th level}, you may add infusions points to an Enduring Enchantment, taking it further - you may not add more Infusions points than your Maximum Infusion and your infusions last up to a week.
{@b At 12th Level}, you no longer take Constitution damage when you craft an enduring enchantment.

subclassFeature.name: Expeditious Enchanter
entries: At 5th level, you may effect you daily crafting productivity from 25gp a day (DMG pg. 129) for magical goods with your Infusion points. So that at 5th level they would have 35gp productivity of work a day for magical goods. (and from 5 gp a day for mundane to 15gp a day)

subclassFeature.name: Increased Infusions
entries: At 11th level, your Maximum Infusion Pool in increased by (2 x INTelligence bonus.)

subclassFeature.name: Frugal Fabricator
entries: Starting at 9th level, every eldritch cannon you create is more destructive:

items: At 14th level, the costs (gold) for the infusions is Â½ the listed expense and 1 less Infusion point (Minimum 1 pt) - provided you are able to work on your project for 2 hours each day your work is not lost.

subclassFeature.name: Phantom Blade
entries: Some rogues choose to focus their training on ways to blend magical talent with their rogue talents. Over time, this training gave way to a group of rogues that learned how to create and use a personal extradimensional space to support their talents. At first, this space was used to stash useful and important items from prying eyes and wandering hands. As these rogues developed greater and more fine-tuned ability to manipulate this space, a new form of attack took shape. Because of the peculiar and distinctive nature of this attack, these rogues came to be known as phantom blades.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain the ability to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|class=warlock}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn three cantrips: {@spell phantom stash|phtm}, {@spell phantom recall|phtm} and {@spell phantom blade|phtm} at 3rd level.
At 7th level, 11th, and 15th level you gain an additional cantrip.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Phantom Blade table shows how many spell slots you have. The table also shows what the level of those slots is; all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your Phantom Blade spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest. For example, when you are 7th level, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell {@spell witch bolt|PhB}, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know one 1st-level warlock spell of your choice. The Spells Known column of the Phantom Blade Spellcasting table shows when you learn more warlock spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be a conjuration or enchantment spell of your choice and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level. Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the warlock spells you know with another spell of your choice from the warlock spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be a conjuration or enchantment.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your warlock spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when selling the saving throw DC for a warlock spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Phantom Zone
entries: At 3rd level, you develop connection to an extra dimensional pocket that only you can access. This pocket space is separate from your inventory and can contain 2 lbs or 8 cubic feet of content. The contents do not count against your encumbrance. If the character dies, their pocket dimension collapses and its contents are lost to Astral Space.
This space grows an additional 1 lb. per level, and a larger container at 5th (16 ft.Â³), 11th(27 ft.Â³) and 42 ft.Â³ cubic feet at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Phantom Augmentations
entries: You develop augmentations which agument your phantasmal space abilities. At 4th level, you gain a phantasmal augmentation of your choice. Your augmentations options are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain phantom blade levels, you gain additional agumentations of your choice, as shown in the Augmentations Known column of the Phantom Blade table.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Ambush
entries: At 9th level, at the end of your round, if you hit a creature with your phantom blade ability, you can choose to manifest a ghostly image of the weapon you used to make the attack. This manifested blade must appear adjacent to the creature you hit. If your attack hit multiple creatures, you choose which square adjacent of one of those creatures your manifested blade appears. The manifest blade counts an ally using the help action and so grants advantage to attacks against its chosen creature. They only last until the end of your next turn.
{@creature Manifest Blade|phtm}

It uses your saves and if your manifested blade is subjected to an effect that allows a Dexterity save for half damage, it instead takes no damage on a successful save. If an enemy would provoke an opportunity attack from your manifested blade, you can use your reaction to direct it to attack that enemy. Using this ability does not require any additional action, but it does occupy your concentration while active. If you attempt to use this ability while it is already active, all currently manifested blades vanish before any new manifested blades appear.

subclassFeature.name: Opportunistic Reaction
entries: At 13th level, you gain the ability to build off even small advantages, if you have advantage on a creature that exposes itself to an Attack of Opportunity from you, if the weapon allows for such, you may also apply sneak damage. At 13th level, your Manifest Blade gain the ability to build off even small advantages, if a creature within range of the Manifest Blade moves out of its threaten space and evokes an attack of opportunity - you no long need to use your reaction for the Manifest Blade to make its attack - it does so separately. The Manifest blade deals sneak attack damage on a successful strike. While manifested, the blades now (Rogue's choice) Either:

items: {@b Parry}: dancing about they impose disadvantage on the creature's next attack, or
{@b Distract}: grant advantage on the next attack against the creature. (It still remains an ally for the purposes of Rogue sneak attack or pack tactics.

subclassFeature.name: Phantom Ambush
entries: At 17th level, your manifest blade ability improves. If your attack hits multiple creatures, you can now manifest a ghostly image of your weapon adjacent to each of them. If any enemy provokes an opportunity attack from a manifested blade, you can use your reaction your attack of opportunity against an enemy that leaves a space your weapon threatens.

Troubor, Bard, Minstrel, Gleeman, and Loremaster. All are names that talk about those spirits of adventure, whose use music,poetry, and dance bring merriment and delight. They distract and delude their audience bringing hope to hopeless and respite to those souls weary from the fight.
But, there is a darker side.

The Anti-Bard. The Dirge. Nilhilism embodied. Part Bard, Part Warlock, Part Cleric - even though they themselves do not believe in god(s) - or at the very least they don't believe there is any reason for them to interact with the Mortal Realms and that even if gods did their interdictions would only make things complicated on a level that no mortal could untangle thus necessitating the gods further interceded to solve the mess they already created, causeing...
Well, you get it.

Unlike Warlocks, the Dirges haven't formed an alliance with a lower realm, the Greater Fey, certainly not the elder gods or the like. But like Warlocks the class has Invocation like abilities called "Mehs" which are gained as they level so that very few Dirges will really ever appear to have similar powers.
While Bards do have specific colleges, Dirges will fixate upon specific aspects of their nihilistic philosophy.
They delight in confounding the faithful, existential crisses, and shattering the veil of the mass delussion of popular held possitions.
In short... they're 'that guy' (or gal).
ie. Assholes.
These are the dark harbingers, the Luckeaters, Mirthless, the Joyless ones,... the Dark Souls.
Dirges recite histories, statistics and use their companions and opponent's insecurities as whetstones upon which they hone their abilities.
They disprove the saying "Sticks and Stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me."

Artificers are the practical technicians of the magical world. Unlike wizards or sorcerers who pursue more theoretical research, or clerics and druids who are tied to the mandates of their deities or churches, artificers take the practice of magic and tailor it to the needs of the situation. From maintaining complex enhancements along lightning rail lines or on board an elemental airship, to customizing the combat enchantments for a strike team deep behind enemy lines, artificers take the magic that is already at hand and apply it in a more efficient manner, essentially getting more spell for the silver.

entries.name: Arcane Science
entries: In the world of Eberron, arcane magic has been harnessed as a form of science and deployed throughout society. Artificers reflect this development. Their knowledge of magical devices, and their ability to infuse mundane items with magic, allows Eberron's most miraculous projects to continue.

During the Last War, artificers were marshaled on a massive scale. Many lives were saved because of the inventions of brave artificers, but countless lives were also lost because of the mass destruction unleashed by their creations.

entries.name: Seekers of New Lore
entries: Nothing excites an artificer quite like uncovering a new metal or discovering a source of elemental energy. In artificer circles, new inventions and strange discoveries create the most excitement. Artificers who wish to make their mark must innovate, creating something fresh, rather than iterating on familiar designs.

This drive for novelty pushes artificers to become adventurers. Eberron's main travel routes and populated regions have long since been explored. Thus, artificers seek the frontiers of civilization in hopes of making the next great discovery in arcane research.

entries.name: Creating an Artificer
entries: An artificer is the preeminent engineer of magical goods and supplies. Consider what drives your artificer to study and experiment. Is if for fame? For the sake of their knowledge? Proof of concept? Is it under the belief they can make a difference? Or is it really about money?

Think about what your artificer is more focused on. In addition to their main interest a within creation, there will be latitude for most to do other things, but the different schools are better at a certain abilities.

entries.name: Artificers in Other Worlds
entries: Eberron is the world most associated with artificers, yet the class can be found throughout the D&D multiverse. In the Forgotten Realms, for example, the island of Lantan is home to many artificers, and in the world of Dragonlance, tinker gnomes are often members of this class. The strange technologies in the Barrier Peaks of the World of Greyhawk have inspired some folk to walk the path of the artificer, and in Mystara, various nations employ artificers to keep airships and other wondrous devices operational. In the City of Sigil, artificers share discoveries from throughout the cosmos, and one in particular—the gnome inventor Vi—has run a multiverse-spanning business from there since leaving the world of her birth, Eberron. In the world-city Ravnica, the Izzet League trains numerous artificers, the destructiveness of whom is unparalleled in other worlds—except, perhaps, by the tinker gnomes of Krynn.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: â€¢ If you want to be at the edge of the battlefield, combat medic, empower your team directly through draughts, potions and consumables  - play the Alchemist.
â€¢ If you want to avoid battlefields, be an Ian Fleming-esque "Q", help fund the group's  ambitions, and be truly focused on magical item creation - Play the Mystic Sage.
â€¢ If you want to be in the middle of the battlefield, striding through with empowered armor & weapon, and enchant those around you - play the Battlesmith.
â€¢ If you want to lead a horde of minions - play the Clockwork Engineer. â€¢ and If you want more utility class with spell casting and item creation - play an Arcane Engineer.

entries.name: Optional Rule: Multiclassing
entries: If your group uses the optional rule on multiclassing in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, here's what you need to know if you choose artificer as one of your classes.

entries.name: Ability Score Minimum
entries: As a multiclass character, you must have at least an Intelligence score of 15 to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already an artificer.

entries.name: Proficiencies Gained
entries: If artificer isn't your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level as an artificer: light armor, medium armor, shields, thieves' tools, tinker's tools.
